definitions.definition: To repeat , as what has been already said; to tell over again; to recite .
examples: There’s no need to rehearse the same old argument; we’ve heard it before, and we all agree.

definitions.definition: To narrate ; to relate ; to tell ; to recount.
examples: The witness rehearsed the events of the night before for the listening detectives.

definitions.definition: To practise by recitation or repetition in private for experiment and improvement, prior to a public representation, especially in theater .
examples: The main actors spent on average two hours a day rehearsing before the first night.
The lawyer advised her client to rehearse her testimony before the trial date.

definitions.definition: To cause to rehearse; to instruct by rehearsal .
examples: The director rehearsed the cast incessantly in the days leading up to opening night, and as a result they were tired and cranky when it arrived.

definitions.definition: To contrive and carefully prepare (a story, etc.) to offer consistency.
examples: The Crown argued that the accused had rehearsed her story.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To repeat , as what has been already said; to tell over again; to recite .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To narrate ; to relate ; to tell ; to recount.
( ambitransitive ) To practise by recitation or repetition in private for experiment and improvement, prior to a public representation, especially in theater .
( transitive , theater ) To cause to rehearse; to instruct by rehearsal .
To contrive and carefully prepare (a story, etc.) to offer consistency.
